issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
Opening this bug to discuss how the Node Controller(s)' state is represented to the Administrator. My understanding is this can often be an incorrect representation of the state of the nodes, cluster, etc.. 

Some potential issues to discuss:
1) A node which is registered and transitions to ENABLED state will continue to report per CLC 'ENABLED' state regardless of the state of the NC process.
 
2) Correlating 'availability' or lack of can be difficult without proper NODE state tracking. In a larger cluster this can take a fair amount of unnecessary Admin work to debug, monitor and resolve. 

3) Migrations may fail in non-obvious ways when specifying a destination host. 

4) The state of a node can not accurately represent the Node's ability to successfully run a functioning instance. For example if eucanetd is not running. 
5) Node's state and/or faults can possibly be reported out of band (ie per monitoring or admin side scripting). If we decide a separate method is what an admin should use for determining Node health/state, then I suggest we rename the current node 'enabled' state to something more informative like 'registered'. 

Still investigating so some of the above may not be accurate. Please correct where needed. 
Thanks!
-M
fields.summary: Node state is not accurately represented by describe nodes

comments.body: please talk to [~chuck]ck for further context.

Currently, describe-nodes is implemented using DescribeServices -t node -A. To update the NODE's service state (the NODE is another hidden service), DescribeResources should be called to CC. After the code review, I found that the NODE's service state is not updated while CC is in ENABLED state. So it means the NODE's state is only updated when the cloud is started or CC's state is changed. (there's also a case that when an instance is requested, CLC updates disabled NODE's state, but that's not important here for the solution).

So probably there are multiple ways to solve this:
1) Continuously update the NODE's state by sending DescribeResources to CC. 
2) Update at the time the node's accurate state is necessary (like migrate-instances)

Either way fixing the state-reporting problem shouldn't be that difficult (1-2 days?)
[~kedwards] [~viglesias] If we choose to fix this in 4.1., I think it's doable. It's your call.

[~spark], are you suggesting in (1) to add node status to DescribeResourceReply message? (DescribeResources message is already sent to CC periodically.) From NC, we propagate node state using {{nodeStatus}} in DescribeResourceResponse:

{code}
    <xs:complexType name="ncDescribeResourceResponseType">
      <xs:complexContent>
        <xs:extension base="tns:eucalyptusMessage">
          <xs:sequence>
            <xs:element name="nodeStatus" type="xs:string"/>
            <xs:element name="migrationCapable" type="xs:boolean"/>
            <xs:element name="iqn" type="xs:string"/>
            <xs:element name="memorySizeMax" type="xs:int"/>
            <xs:element name="memorySizeAvailable" type="xs:int"/>
            <xs:element name="diskSizeMax" type="xs:int"/>
            <xs:element name="diskSizeAvailable" type="xs:int"/>
            <xs:element name="numberOfCoresMax" type="xs:int"/>
            <xs:element name="numberOfCoresAvailable" type="xs:int"/>
            <xs:element name="publicSubnets" type="xs:string"/>
          </xs:sequence>
        </xs:extension>
      </xs:complexContent>
    </xs:complexType>
{code}

That could be propagated, along with the IQN, to ccNodeType, which is returned as array of nodes in DescribeResourcesResponse:

{code}
      <xs:complexType name="ccNodeType">
        <xs:sequence>
          <xs:element minOccurs="0" name="serviceTag" type="xs:string"/>
          <xs:element minOccurs="0" name="iqn" type="xs:string"/>
          <xs:element name="nodeStatus" type="xs:string"/>
        </xs:sequence>
      </xs:complexType>
{code}

Is that what you had in mind?
This reminds me of work that [~vasya] was recently doing, propagating hypervisor information from NC up to CLC....

[~dmitrii] The immediate fix I had in mind was limited to CLC. Currently CLC doesn't address NC's state transitions ENABLED -> SOMETHING_ELSE. That fix (local to CLC) assumes that CC reports CLC the accurate information about NC (broken, missing, or else).

Expanding the DescribeResourcesResponse might address #4 of Matt's description. It could be the next step.

I don't believe your assumption holds, [~spark]. Currently, CC does not report anything about nodes other than "serviceTag" (the URL of the NC service) and "iqn", in the {{DescribeResourcesResponse}}:

{code}
        ...
        <n:nodes>
          <n:serviceTag>http://10.111.5.174:8775/axis2/services/EucalyptusNC</n:serviceTag>
          <n:iqn>iqn.1994-05.com.redhat:f7b169fd8413</n:iqn>
        </n:nodes>
      </n:DescribeResourcesResponse>
{code}

[~vasya] may have added another field there for the hypervisor. Also, {{DescribeServicesResponse}} only contains information about CC service, not any of the NCs.

So, I think a change to the CC (and its WSDL) may be needed before CLC can report on node's status. Unless I am missing something.
[~dmitrii], yes I've added hypervisor into DescribeResourcesResponse and now it is propagated to CLC from NC and Broker.
[~dmitrii] Ok. Does CC removes the service tag of the NC if the NC is no longer reachable from CC?

[~dmitrii] [~spark] The CC reports the NC node state via a DescribeServices call.

Example request to the CC:
{code}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<euca:DescribeServicesType xmlns:euca="http://msgs.eucalyptus.com/4.0.2">
  <euca:ServiceTransitionType>
    <euca:EmpyreanMessage>
      <euca:correlationId>7c4ce59f-71d9-45a4-8111-972c26d74976</euca:correlationId>
      <euca:_return>true</euca:_return>
      <euca:_services/>
      <euca:_disabledServices/>
      <euca:_notreadyServices/>
      <euca:_stoppedServices/>
    </euca:EmpyreanMessage>
    <euca:services>
      <euca:item>
        <euca:partition>one</euca:partition>
        <euca:name>10.111.5.200</euca:name>
        <euca:type>node</euca:type>
        <euca:fullName>arn:euca:bootstrap:one:node:10.111.5.200/</euca:fullName>
        <euca:uris>
          <euca:item>
            <euca:entry>http://10.111.5.200:8775/axis2/services/EucalyptusNC</euca:entry>
          </euca:item>
        </euca:uris>
        <euca:uri>http://10.111.5.200:8775/axis2/services/EucalyptusNC</euca:uri>
      </euca:item>
    </euca:services>
  </euca:ServiceTransitionType>
  <euca:serviceNames/>
</euca:DescribeServicesType>
{code}

And the response (In my case the NC is down, hence the NOTREADY response):

{code}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<euca:DescribeServicesResponseType xmlns:euca="http://msgs.eucalyptus.com/4.0.2">
  <euca:EmpyreanMessage>
    <euca:_return>true</euca:_return>
    <euca:_services/>
    <euca:_disabledServices/>
    <euca:_notreadyServices/>
    <euca:_stoppedServices/>
  </euca:EmpyreanMessage>
  <euca:serviceStatuses>
    <euca:item>
      <euca:serviceId>
        <euca:partition>one</euca:partition>
        <euca:name>10.111.5.200</euca:name>
        <euca:type>node</euca:type>
        <euca:uris>
          <euca:item>
            <euca:entry>http://10.111.5.200:8775/axis2/services/EucalyptusNC</euca:entry>
          </euca:item>
        </euca:uris>
      </euca:serviceId>
      <euca:localState>NOTREADY</euca:localState>
      <euca:localEpoch>20</euca:localEpoch>
      <euca:details>
        <euca:item>
          <euca:entry>Error occurred in transport</euca:entry>
        </euca:item>
      </euca:details>
      <euca:statusDetails/>
    </euca:item>
  </euca:serviceStatuses>
</euca:DescribeServicesResponseType>
{code}

Hey, [~sgraham], thanks for chiming in! Are you sure that the XML snippets that you posted above are from CLC<->CC traffic? That's not at all what I am seeing when I sniff port 8774 on the CC host. My CC returns {{<n:serviceStatuses>}} (not {{<euca:serviceStatuses>}}) and only the CC's status is in there. I suspect you're catching status messages exchanged by the Java components (on port 8773) and thus the status of NC's is the value inferred by the CLC.
[~sgraham] [~dmitrii] It is talking to CC and calls DescribeServices to get the status of NCs from reading the code.

And the bug probably is that it is not calling it (in conjunction with DescribeResources) while CC is in ENABLED. So it could be that CC/NC are already reporting the status info (by reading the CLC code, that's the assumption).

[~spark], I just don't see anything in {{DescribeServicesResponse}} that would supply CLC with status of NCs.

{code}
      <n:DescribeServicesResponse xmlns:n="http://eucalyptus.ucsb.edu/">
        <n:correlationId>a1f868a3-f172-4c22-9c5d-ef46fffab959</n:correlationId>
        <n:return>true</n:return>
        <n:serviceStatuses>
          <n:serviceId>
            <n:partition>PARTI00</n:partition>
            <n:type>cluster</n:type>
            <n:name>CC_141</n:name>
            <n:uris>http://10.111.5.141:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC</n:uris>
          </n:serviceId>
          <n:localState>ENABLED</n:localState>
          <n:localEpoch>29</n:localEpoch>
          <n:details>ERRORS=0</n:details>
        </n:serviceStatuses>
      </n:DescribeServicesResponse>
{code}

[~dmitrii] I think the DescribeServices message is not periodically requested for NC's status. If you see [~sgraham]'s earlier comments you see the node info is populated with the request. That's what I see in the code too. There should be other threads that periodically calls DescribeServices. 

I think that special DescribeServices for getting node info should be sent periodically as well, but it is currently not.

Perhaps you're right, [~spark]. What looks strange to me is that the messages in [~sgraham]'s comments involve syntax (e.g., {{<euca:uris>}}) that is not in CC's WSDL, so CC cannot parse/generate them.

After further review I think [~dmitrii]'s right. Although debugger shows the message populated with NC's info, the message never goes out to the wire. Looking at the CC's doDescribeServices impl, it looks like it handles the 'serviceType=node' case, using the cached resource status. So the fix will be to get the doDescribeServices (with serviceType=node) message actually hit the CC.
There was a bug that keeps CLC from sending DescribeServices request to CC, with type=node. It was a sort of race condition that manifests unpredictably.
Woot!

Nice work [~spark],

For posterity I tested out your code change on 4.0.2 and it is working.

Time between each euca-describe-nodes execution is a couple of seconds:
{code}
[root@d-23 eucalyptus]# euca-describe-nodes 
NODE    one             10.111.5.200    ENABLED
[root@d-23 eucalyptus]# euca-describe-nodes 
NODE    one             10.111.5.200    ENABLED
[root@d-23 eucalyptus]# euca-describe-nodes 
NODE    one             10.111.5.200    ENABLED
[root@d-23 eucalyptus]# euca-describe-nodes 
NODE    one             10.111.5.200    DISABLED
[root@d-23 eucalyptus]# euca-describe-nodes 
NODE    one             10.111.5.200    NOTREADY
[root@d-23 eucalyptus]# euca-describe-nodes 
NODE    one             10.111.5.200    NOTREADY
[root@d-23 eucalyptus]# euca-describe-nodes 
NODE    one             10.111.5.200    NOTREADY
{code}

And it also transitions back to ENABLED when I bring the NC back up.

I couldn't figure out where that XML snippet I got above came from...because the ccConfig is definitely going to connect to the CC. I'm not convinced, after looking at my notes again, that the XML is a capture of the interaction between the client and the CLC when someone calls 'euca-describe-nodes'. Now I know that the euca namespace will not show up in the CLC -> CC interaction. 

From the TCP dump between the CLC and CC I see the following:

Request (cut down..):
{code}
<serviceIds><partition>one</partition><type>node</type><name>10.111.5.200</name><uris>http://10.111.5.200:8775/axis2/services/EucalyptusNC</uris></serviceIds></DescribeServices></Body></Envelope>
{code}

Response (WS-Security headers stripped):
{code}
<n:DescribeServicesResponse xmlns:n="http://eucalyptus.ucsb.edu/">
<n:correlationId>1aa391a4-9391-482f-ad02-32c9db3dac51</n:correlationId>
<n:return>true</n:return>
<n:serviceStatuses>
<n:serviceId>
<n:partition>one</n:partition>
<n:type>node</n:type>
<n:name>10.111.5.200</n:name>
<n:uris>http://10.111.5.200:8775/axis2/services/EucalyptusNC</n:uris>
</n:serviceId>
<n:localState>NOTREADY</n:localState>
<n:localEpoch>22</n:localEpoch>
<n:details>Error occurred in transport</n:details>
</n:serviceStatuses>
</n:DescribeServicesResponse>
</soapenv:Body></soapenv:Envelope>
{code}

Hi, 

Node status was changed to NOTREADY status immediately after stopping the NC service on Node controller. And also node status changed to READY state after starting the NC service.

NODE    one             10.111.5.25     NOTREADY
INSTANCE        i-04c61ca2
INSTANCE        i-91f9f022
NODE    one             10.111.5.25     NOTREADY
INSTANCE        i-04c61ca2
NODE    one             10.111.1.100    NOTREADY

This bug is tested in 4.1 and confirmed the issue has been fixed now.

Thanks,
Kasim Shaik.

Fix Verified see comment from [~kshaik]: https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-10136?focusedCommentId=81113&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-81113
